title: Monsoon Alert – Heavy rains in these states including Kerala and Tamil Nadu on Diwali - Times Bull
article_text:
Monsoon Alert – The weather may spoil the joy of Diwali celebrations today. The weather is expected to be inclement for 24 hours. The only relief is that most parts of North India will remain clear. However, there will be some wind and light sunshine in some areas. Temperatures may drop in Delhi-NCR along with light sunshine.

Temperatures may also drop in Himachal Pradesh and Uttarakhand. Winter is now increasing here. Mild morning and evening chills have already begun in Uttar Pradesh and Bihar. The weather will remain inclement in South India. Rain may also be seen in some areas of the northeastern states. The Indian Meteorological Department has issued an important warning for some states. You can find important weather updates.

Snowfall and Rain Warning in Himachal Pradesh

According to the Indian Meteorological Department, the weather in Himachal Pradesh is expected to deteriorate. The IMD has predicted a weak western disturbance affecting the mountainous, or high-altitude, regions from October 21st. An alert has been issued for thunderstorms and light to moderate rain accompanied by strong winds.

According to the IMD, an alert has been issued for rain and snowfall on October 21st and 22nd. This could lead to a sudden drop in temperatures, and a severe winter is expected.

How will the weather be in the northeastern states?

According to the Meteorological Department, the next two days will not be easy in the northeastern states. Thunderstorms and rain are expected at various places in Manipur, Puducherry, and Sikkim. Rainfall is also possible in Arunachal Pradesh, Nagaland, Tripura, and Mizoram. Furthermore, thunderstorms and lightning can also pose a threat to people here. People are urged to exercise caution due to the possibility of lightning.

Rain in many parts of South India

According to the Indian Meteorological Department, an alert for heavy rain has been issued in Kerala, Tamil Nadu, and Telangana. Thunderstorms are also expected here. In addition, thunderstorms and rain could be a disaster for people in parts of Maharashtra, Andhra Pradesh, and Karnataka. Winds of up to 50 kilometres per hour are also expected.

title: സംസ്ഥാനത്ത് കനത്ത മഴ, ഇരട്ട ന്യൂനമർദ്ദ ഭീഷണി, ജില്ലകളിൽ ഓറഞ്ച്, യെല്ലോ അലർട്ട് - Karma News - Voice of common people
article_text:
keralatrending
സംസ്ഥാനത്ത് കനത്ത മഴ, ഇരട്ട ന്യൂനമർദ്ദ ഭീഷണി, ജില്ലകളിൽ ഓറഞ്ച്, യെല്ലോ അലർട്ട്
By Karma News Network -
October 20, 2025

തിരുവനന്തപുരം: സംസ്ഥാനത്ത് തുലാവർഷം ശക്തമായി തുടരുന്നതിനിടെ കാലാവസ്ഥാ വകുപ്പ് പുതിയ മുന്നറിയിപ്പുകൾ പുറപ്പെടുവിച്ചു. തെക്ക് കിഴക്കൻ അറബിക്കടലിലും ബംഗാൾ ഉൾക്കടലിലും രൂപംകൊണ്ട ഇരട്ട ന്യൂനമർദ്ദങ്ങളുടെ സ്വാധീനഫലമായി അടുത്ത ദിവസങ്ങളിലും കനത്ത മഴയ്ക്കാണ് സാധ്യത.

ഇന്ന് എറണാകുളത്തും ഇടുക്കിയിലും ഓറഞ്ച് അലർട്ട് പ്രഖ്യാപിച്ചിട്ടുണ്ട്. കണ്ണൂർ, കാസർകോട് ഒഴികെയുള്ള മറ്റ് ജില്ലകളിൽ യെല്ലോ അലർട്ട് നിലവിലുണ്ട്. ഇടിമിന്നലോടും ശക്തമായ കാറ്റോടും കൂടിയ മഴക്ക് സാധ്യതയുള്ളതിനാൽ ജാഗ്രത പാലിക്കണമെന്ന് കാലാവസ്ഥാ നിരീക്ഷണ കേന്ദ്രം അറിയിച്ചു.

കേരള തീരപ്രദേശങ്ങളിൽ ഉയർന്ന തിരമാലകളും ശക്തമായ കാറ്റും പ്രതീക്ഷിക്കുന്നതിനാൽ മത്സ്യബന്ധനത്തിന് വിലക്ക് തുടരുന്നു. മഴയും കാറ്റും മൂലം തീരപ്രദേശങ്ങളിലെ ജനങ്ങൾ ജാഗ്രത പാലിക്കണമെന്നും അധികൃതർ അറിയിച്ചു.

തുടർച്ചയായ മഴ ലഭിക്കുന്ന മലയോര പ്രദേശങ്ങളിൽ മണ്ണിടിച്ചിൽ സാധ്യത നിലനിൽക്കുന്നതിനാൽ പ്രത്യേക ജാഗ്രത വേണമെന്നും മുന്നറിയിപ്പ്. തെക്ക് കിഴക്കൻ അറബിക്കടലിൽ നിലനിൽക്കുന്ന ന്യൂനമർദ്ദം അടുത്ത മണിക്കൂറുകളിൽ തീവ്ര ന്യൂനമർദ്ദമായി മാറും. അതേസമയം, തെക്ക് കിഴക്കൻ ബംഗാൾ ഉൾക്കടലിലെ ചക്രവാതച്ചുഴിയും ന്യൂനമർദ്ദമായി മാറാനുള്ള സാധ്യതയുണ്ട്.

മിന്നലാഘാതത്തിന്റെ ഭീഷണി നിലനിൽക്കുന്നതിനാൽ ഇടിമിന്നൽ സമയങ്ങളിൽ കെട്ടിടങ്ങൾക്കുള്ളിൽ തുടരാൻ വിദഗ്ധർ നിർദേശിക്കുന്നു. മിന്നലേറ്റ ആളിന് വൈദ്യുത പ്രവാഹം ശരീരത്തിൽ നിലനിൽക്കുന്നില്ല, അതിനാൽ പ്രഥമ ശുശ്രൂഷ നൽകാൻ മടിക്കരുത്. അടിയന്തിരമായി വൈദ്യ സഹായം ഉറപ്പാക്കണം.

അതേസമയം, മുല്ലപ്പെരിയാർ അണക്കെട്ട് തുറന്നതിനാൽ, സമീപപ്രദേശങ്ങളിലുള്ളവർ ജലാശയങ്ങളിലോ നദീതീരങ്ങളിലോ ഇറങ്ങുന്നത് ഒഴിവാക്കണമെന്നും അധികാരികൾ അറിയിച്ചു.

mainstory
rain alert

കഴക്കൂട്ടത്ത് യുവതിയെ ഹോസ്റ്റലിൽ കയറി പീഡിപ്പിച്ചത് ലോറിഡ്രൈവർ, പ്രതി കുറ്റം സമ്മതിച്ചു

title: Heavy rain likely as NE monsoon stays active over Kerala; orange alert in Ernakulam, Idukki today - Onmanorama
article_text:
PUBLISHED: OCTOBER 20, 2025 06:48 AM IST UPDATED: OCTOBER 20, 2025 06:57 AM IST
Thiruvananthapuram: The northeast monsoon continues to remain active over Kerala, with the India Meteorological Department (IMD) forecasting heavy to very heavy rainfall and thunderstorms across several districts in the coming days.
According to the IMD, the well-marked low-pressure area over the southeast Arabian Sea and Lakshadweep region off the Kerala–Karnataka coasts is likely to move west-northwestwards and intensify into a depression within the next 24 hours. Meanwhile, an upper air cyclonic circulation over the south Andaman Sea and adjoining southeast Bay of Bengal is expected to give rise to another low-pressure area around October 21. This system may intensify into a depression over the central and adjoining west-central parts of the south Bay of Bengal in the following 48 hours.
Another cyclonic circulation now lies over south Kerala and the adjoining Comorin area. A trough extends from the well-marked low-pressure area over the southeast Arabian Sea to the southwest Bay of Bengal across the cyclonic circulation over south Kerala, Comorin, and Sri Lanka.
Thunderstorms accompanied by lightning and gusty winds reaching speeds of 30–40 kmph are very likely to occur at one or two places over Kerala and Lakshadweep till October 23. The IMD has issued a warning to fishermen in Kerala and Lakshadweep, advising them not to venture into the sea till October 25 due to rough conditions and strong winds.
An orange alert (very heavy rainfall of 12–20 cm in 24 hours) has been issued for the following districts:
A yellow alert (heavy rainfall of 7–11 cm in 24 hours) has been issued for:
The IMD has urged residents in the alert zones to remain cautious, avoid waterlogged areas, and follow instructions from local authorities.

title: IMD predicts very heavy rainfall in Tamil Nadu; clear skies likely in Delhi-NCR - DD News
article_text:
According to the latest forecast from the India Meteorological Department (IMD), enhanced rainfall activity is likely to persist across South India in the coming week, with isolated heavy to very heavy showers expected over Kerala, Tamil Nadu and Puducherry during the next seven days. Tamil Nadu is likely to see very heavy rainfall between October 15 and 17, while Kerala and Mahé are likely to experience very heavy rainfall on October 16 and 17.

Conditions are favourable for the complete withdrawal of the southwest monsoon from the remaining parts of the country within the next 24 hours. Simultaneously, the setting in of easterly and northeasterly winds over southern peninsular India and the adjoining Bay of Bengal is expected to mark the onset of the northeast monsoon rainfall over the southeast peninsular region during the same period.

In the past 24 hours (ending at 8:30 a.m. on October 15), heavy to very heavy rainfall was recorded at isolated places in Tamil Nadu and Kerala, while coastal Karnataka experienced heavy rainfall.

IMD defines heavy rain as rainfall between 64.5 mm and 115.5 mm, very heavy rain as rainfall between 115.6 mm and 204.4 mm, and extremely heavy rain as rainfall exceeding 204.4 mm.

Meanwhile, in Delhi-NCR, dry and clear conditions are set to continue through October 18.

On Wednesday, skies are expected to remain mainly clear, with maximum temperatures ranging between 31°C and 33°C – about 1-2°C below normal. Winds will be northwesterly in the afternoon at speeds of 5-10 kmph, turning northeasterly and lighter in the evening.

Mornings from October 16-18 are likely to be hazy or misty. Maximum temperatures will hover around 31-34°C, while minimum temperatures will range from 16-20°C.

On 16 October, both daytime and night-time temperatures are expected to be below normal, with calm morning winds strengthening slightly by afternoon. On 17 October, minimum temperatures should rise marginally, while maximums remain near normal. Northerly winds may pick up in the afternoon before easing again at night. Similar conditions are expected on 18 October, with no significant change in temperatures.

The contrast in weather patterns highlights the seasonal transition underway – while southern India braces for the northeast monsoon, northern plains are entering a period of stable, clear post-monsoon conditions. Authorities have advised residents in southern states to remain alert to the potential impacts of heavy rainfall, including localised flooding and waterlogging.

other_info.csv_title: IMD predicts very heavy rainfall in Tamil Nadu; clear skies likely in Delhi-NCR - DD News
